children.displayTitle: [F]  904.13.4 Special Provisions for Automatic Sprinkler Systems
children.titleText: Special Provisions for Automatic Sprinkler Systems

children.body: Sprinklers used for the protection of fryers shall be tested in accordance with UL 199E, listed for that application and installed in accordance with their listing.

Cooktops and ranges installed in the following occupancies shall be protected in accordance with Section 904.14.1:
  1. In Group I-1 occupancies where domestic cooking facilities are installed in accordance with Section 420.9.
  2. In Group I-2 occupancies where domestic cooking facilities are installed in accordance with Section 407.2.7.
  3. In Group R-2 college dormitories where domestic cooking facilities are installed in accordance with Section 420.11.

diagrams.title: Cooking Facilities: R-2 Dorms
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Dorm rooms on college campuses are allowed to include domestic (residential) cooking appliances indicated by 420.10.1, including ovens, cooktops, ranges, warmers, coffee makers and microwaves. Cooktops and ranges must be installed under a vent hood meeting the mechanical code. There are two methods specified by FC 904.13 to reduce potential of a cooking fire that will extend to the room contents. Option one is to provide vent hood with a fire suppression system meeting the requirements of UL3000A. Option two is to install equipment that is tested and listed to prevent ignition of cooking oil with burners turned on to their maximum heat settings and allowed to operate for 30 minutes.

Regardless of the protection provided, ranges and cooktops are not permitted to be installed in sleeping rooms. However, microwaves, coffee pots and warmers may be used in sleeping rooms.

diagrams.title: Domestic Cooking Appliances in Group I-2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group I-2 occupancies the only cooking appliances allowed are ovens, cooktops, ranges, warmers and microwaves. A portable fire extinguisher installed per Section 906 is required to be located within 30' of any cooking appliance. Cooktops and ranges need to be protected in accordance w/ 904.14. A fuel and electric power shut-off accessible only to staff must be provided. A timer(s) shall automatically deactivate all appliances such that each appliance may not operate continuously for more than120 minutes.

children.body: Cooktops and ranges shall be protected in accordance with Section 904.14.1.1 or 904.14.1.2.

The domestic recirculating or exterior vented cooking hood provided over the cooktop or range shall be equipped with an approved automatic fire-extinguishing system complying with the following:
  1. The automatic fire-extinguishing system shall be of a type recognized for protection of domestic cooking equipment. Preengineered automatic fire-extinguishing systems shall be listed and labeled in accordance with UL 300A and installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
  2. Manual actuation of the fire-extinguishing system shall be provided in accordance with Section 904.13.1.
  3. Interconnection of the fuel and electric power supply shall be in accordance with Section 904.13.2.

Cooktops and ranges shall include burners that have been tested and listed to prevent ignition of cooking oil with burners turned on to their maximum heat settings and allowed to operate for 30 minutes.

diagrams.title: Standpipes at Horiz. Exits and Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At horizontal exits the code requires a class I connection (FDC/Fire Department Connection) is provided on both sides of the wall regardless of the direction of egress through the horizontal exit opening. Because a horizontal exit cannot be the only exit and the code requires a class I connection at the main floor landing inside of required interior exit stairways there is an exception made for where the stairway FDC would be able to address the same area as the FDC at the horizontal exit. The FDC at the horizontal exit facing a required exit stairway may be omitted when all floor areas between the exits are reachable from the stairway FDC by a 30' hose stream from a 100' hose connected to the stairway FDC.

diagrams.title: Standpipe Types
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Standpipes, Types: - There are five types of standpipes - automatic dry, automatic wet, manual dry, manual wet, and semiautomatic dry. Automatic dry systems are pressurized with air, when a hose valve is opened, the air is released and the system fills with water. Automatic wet systems are filled with water at all times. Manual dry systems are not connected to a water supply, and must be supplied with water from the fire department. This is done via a fire department connection (FDC). Manual wet systems are filled with water, but require a supplemental fire department connection to meet required demand. Semiautomatic dry systems do not have water in them, but when a hose valve is opened, a remote switch opens the valve and allows water to fill the system.

diagrams.title: Standpipe System Classes
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Standpipe Systems - There are three classification of standpipes:
  • Class I standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection and are intended for fire department use only.
  • Class II standpipes are equipped with a 1-1/2" hose and connection, and are intended primarily for building occupant use.
  • Class III standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection, reduced down to a 1-1/2" connected hose. These are intended for use by building occupants and fire department personnel.

children.body: Standpipe systems shall be provided in new buildings and structures in accordance with Sections 905.2 through 905.11. In buildings used for high-piled combustible storage, fire protection shall be in accordance with the International Fire Code.

diagrams.title: High Piled Storage (definition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
High-piled storage refers to storage methods where items are stacked above a certain height, typically more than 12 feet. This can include:
  • Solid-piled storage: Items stacked directly on top of each other.
  • Palletized storage: Use of pallets to stack and organize goods.
  • Rack storage: Systems involving shelving units or racks for organization at various heights.
  • Bin box and shelf storage: Smaller units or shelves that are installed at high levels for additional storage capacity.
These methods maximize vertical space in warehouses or storage facilities, often requiring specific safety and construction considerations.

children.body: Standpipe systems shall be installed in accordance with this section and NFPA 14. Fire department connections for standpipe systems shall be in accordance with Section 912.

Standpipe systems shall be installed where required by Sections 905.3.1 through 905.3.8. Standpipe systems are allowed to be combined with automatic sprinkler systems.
Exception: Standpipe systems are not required in Group R-3 occupancies.

diagrams.title: High Rise: Emergency Systems
diagrams.descriptionHtml: High-rise buildings have special requirements for emergency systems that must be in place. These systems include, full fire alarm system with additional smoke detection and emergency voice/alarm communications system, a standpipe system (permitted to be part of the sprinkler system), emergency responder radio coverage, a smoke removal system. All of these must be tied into the required fire command center. Standby and emergency power is required to run essential systems in case of emergency.

children.body:
Class III standpipe systems shall be installed throughout buildings where any of the following conditions exist:
  1. Four or more stories are above or below grade plane.
  2. The floor level of the highest story is located more than 30 feet (9144 mm) above the lowest level of fire department vehicle access.
  3. The floor level of the lowest story is located more than 30 feet (9144 mm) below the highest level of fire department vehicle access.
Exceptions:
  1. Class I standpipes are allowed in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  2. Class I standpipes are allowed in Group B and E occupancies.
  3. Class I standpipes are allowed in parking garages.
  4. Class I standpipes are allowed in basements equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system.
  5. Class I standpipes are allowed in buildings where occupant-use hose lines will not be utilized by trained personnel or the fire department.
  6. In determining the lowest level of fire department vehicle access, it shall not be required to consider either of the following:
    1. Recessed loading docks for four vehicles or less.
    2. Conditions where topography makes access from the fire department vehicle to the building impractical or impossible.

Class I automatic wet standpipes shall be provided in nonsprinklered Group A buildings having an occupant load exceeding 1,000 persons.
Exceptions:
  1. Open-air-seating spaces without enclosed spaces.
  2. Class I automatic dry and semiautomatic dry standpipes or manual wet standpipes are allowed in buildings that are not high-rise buildings.

Covered mall and open mall buildings shall be equipped throughout with a standpipe system where required by Section 905.3.1. Mall buildings not required to be equipped with a standpipe system by Section 905.3.1 shall be equipped with Class I hose connections connected to the automatic sprinkler system sized to deliver water at 250 gallons per minute (946.4 L/min) at the hydraulically most remote hose connection while concurrently supplying the automatic sprinkler system demand. The standpipe system shall be designed to not exceed a 50 pounds per square inch (psi) (345 kPa) residual pressure loss with a flow of 250 gallons per minute (946.4 L/min) from the fire department connection to the hydraulically most remote hose connection. Hose connections shall be provided at each of the following locations:
  1. Within the mall at the entrance to each exit passageway or corridor.
  2. At each floor-level landing within interior exit stairways opening directly on the mall.
  3. At exterior public entrances to the mall of a covered mall building.
  4. At public entrances at the perimeter line of an open mall building.
  5. At other locations as necessary so that the distance to reach all portions of a tenant space does not exceed 200 feet (60 960 mm) from a hose connection.

Stages greater than 1,000 square feet in area (93 m2) shall be equipped with a Class III wet standpipe system with 11/2-inch and 21/2-inch (38 mm and 64 mm) hose connections on each side of the stage.
Exception: Where the building or area is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system, a 11/2-inch (38 mm) hose connection shall be installed in accordance with NFPA 13 or in accordance with NFPA 14 for Class II or III standpipes.

The 11/2-inch (38 mm) hose connections shall be equipped with sufficient lengths of 11/2-inch (38 mm) hose to provide fire protection for the stage area. Hose connections shall be equipped with an approved adjustable fog nozzle and be mounted in a cabinet or on a rack.
Underground buildings shall be equipped throughout with a Class I automatic wet or manual wet standpipe system.

Buildings with a rooftop helistop or heliport shall be equipped with a Class I or III standpipe system extended to the roof level on which the helistop or heliport is located in accordance with Section 2007.5 of the International Fire Code.
Standpipes in marinas and boatyards shall comply with Chapter 36 of the International Fire Code.
Buildings or structures that have landscaped roofs and that are equipped with a standpipe system shall have the standpipe system extended to the roof level on which the landscaped roof is located.

Class I standpipe hose connections shall be provided in all of the following locations:
  1. In every required interior exit stairway, a hose connection shall be provided for each story above and below grade plane. Hose connections shall be located at the main floor landing unless otherwise approved by the fire code official.
    Exception: A single hose connection shall be permitted to be installed in the open corridor or open breezeway between open stairs that are not greater than 75 feet (22 860 mm) apart.
  2. On each side of the wall adjacent to the exit opening of a horizontal exit.
    Exception: Where floor areas adjacent to a horizontal exit are reachable from an interior exit stairway hose connection by a 30-foot (9144 mm) hose stream from a nozzle attached to 100 feet (30 480 mm) of hose, a hose connection shall not be required at the horizontal exit.
  3. In every exit passageway, at the entrance from the exit passageway to other areas of a building.
    Exception: Where floor areas adjacent to an exit passageway are reachable from an interior exit stairway hose connection by a 30-foot (9144 mm) hose stream from a nozzle attached to 100 feet (30 480 mm) of hose, a hose connection shall not be required at the entrance from the exit passageway to other areas of the building.
  4. In covered mall buildings, adjacent to each exterior public entrance to the mall and adjacent to each entrance from an exit passageway or exit corridor to the mall. In open mall buildings, adjacent to each public entrance to the mall at the perimeter line and adjacent to each entrance from an exit passageway or exit corridor to the mall.
  5. Where the roof has a slope less than 4 units vertical in 12 units horizontal (33.3-percent slope), a hose connection shall be located to serve the roof or at the highest landing of an interior exit stairway with access to the roof provided in accordance with Section 1011.12.
  6. Where the most remote portion of a nonsprinklered floor or story is more than 150 feet (45 720 mm) from a hose connection or the most remote portion of a sprinklered floor or story is more than 200 feet (60 960 mm) from a hose connection, the fire code official is authorized to require that additional hose connections be provided in approved locations.

diagrams.title: Standpipes at Horiz. Exits and Stairways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At horizontal exits the code requires a class I connection (FDC/Fire Department Connection) is provided on both sides of the wall regardless of the direction of egress through the horizontal exit opening. Because a horizontal exit cannot be the only exit and the code requires a class I connection at the main floor landing inside of required interior exit stairways there is an exception made for where the stairway FDC would be able to address the same area as the FDC at the horizontal exit. The FDC at the horizontal exit facing a required exit stairway may be omitted when all floor areas between the exits are reachable from the stairway FDC by a 30' hose stream from a 100' hose connected to the stairway FDC.

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exit Egress Analysis
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When used correctly, in certain situations, use of a horizontal exit can reduce the number of stairways provided while maintaining a consistent level of protection for all occupants. With certain exceptions, horizontal exits are limited to satisfying no more than 50% of the required exits, exit capacity or exit width required from a space under consideration. They may not serve as the only exit from any space. The space to which a horizontal exit leads must be a public area, or occupied by the same tenant and shall serve as a refuge area. The refuge area must be of sufficient size to accommodate the occupants existing in the space and the occupants entering the space assuming 3 s.f. per person for the combined occupant load.

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A horizontal exit compartmentalizes a building allowing occupants to exit the area containing the origin of a fire into another portion of the building that is protected by fire-resistance-rated assemblies (doors, walls, ceilings, and floors). A horizontal exit separates a space into two exit access areas. Code requirements for horizontal exits address fire-rated separation, opening protectives, capacity, and other features.

diagrams.title: Standpipe System Classes
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Standpipe Systems - There are three classification of standpipes:
  • Class I standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection and are intended for fire department use only.
  • Class II standpipes are equipped with a 1-1/2" hose and connection, and are intended primarily for building occupant use.
  • Class III standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection, reduced down to a 1-1/2" connected hose. These are intended for use by building occupants and fire department personnel.

children.displayTitle: [F]  905.4 Location of Class I Standpipe Hose Connections
children.titleText: Location of Class I Standpipe Hose Connections

children.body:
Risers and laterals of Class I standpipe systems not located within an interior exit stairway shall be protected by a degree of fire resistance equal to that required for vertical enclosures in the building in which they are located.
Exception: In buildings equipped throughout with an approved automatic sprinkler system, laterals that are not located within an interior exit stairway are not required to be enclosed within fire-resistance-rated construction.
In buildings where more than one standpipe is provided, the standpipes shall be interconnected in accordance with NFPA 14.

Class II standpipe hose connections located so that all portions of the building are within 30 feet (9144 mm) of a nozzle attached to 100 feet (30 480 mm) of hose. Class II standpipe hose connections shall be located where they will have ready access.

diagrams.title: Standpipe System Classes
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Standpipe Systems - There are three classification of standpipes:
  • Class I standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection and are intended for fire department use only.
  • Class II standpipes are equipped with a 1-1/2" hose and connection, and are intended primarily for building occupant use.
  • Class III standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection, reduced down to a 1-1/2" connected hose. These are intended for use by building occupants and fire department personnel.

children.displayTitle: [F]  905.5 Location of Class II Standpipe Hose Connections
children.titleText: Location of Class II Standpipe Hose Connections

children.body: In Group A-1 and A-2 occupancies having occupant loads exceeding 1,000 persons, hose connections shall be located on each side of any stage, on each side of the rear of the auditorium, on each side of the balcony and on each tier of dressing rooms.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Group A-1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A-1 occupancies are those spaces used for viewing of performances or movies. These can include movie theaters, concert halls, and similar structures. Sprinklers are required to be installed in these spaces when a single fire area exceeds 12,000 sq. ft., or there is a total occupant load of 300 or more, or when the A-1 classified space is not on the level of exit discharge (i.e., stairs up or down must be used to access the exit to the public way), or where there are multiple theater viewing rooms within the same fire area. Where the A-1 occupancy is located on a floor other than that of the level of exit discharge, all floors between the A-1 occupancy and the level of egress are required to be sprinklered. If this assembly space is on a roof that exceeds a 300 person occupant load, all floors between the occupied roof and the level of exit discharge are required to be sprinklered (see, Section 903.2.1.6).

Sprinkler requirements are determined by a number of different criteria and are dependent on divisions of the building into one or more fire areas. However, in some states, sprinkler requirements may be more restrictive at a local or fire district level. Check with local building and fire jurisdictions to see if local building and/or fire codes have more restrictive requirements, such as for those buildings located in a Wildfire Urban Interface area.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Group A-2
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Group A-2 occupancies are those spaces intended for food and drink consumption. These can include night clubs, restaurants, bars, and similar spaces. Sprinklers are required to be installed in these spaces when a single fire area exceeds 5,000 sq. ft., or there is a total occupant load of 100 or more within the space, or when the A-2 classified space is not on the level of exit discharge (i.e., stairs must be traversed up or down to access the exit to the public way). Where the A-2 occupancy is located on a floor other than that of the level of exit discharge, all floors between the A-2 occupancy and the level of egress are required to be sprinklered. If this assembly space is on a roof that exceeds a 100 person occupant load, all floors between the occupied roof and the level of exit discharge are required to be sprinklered (see, Section 903.2.1.6).

Sprinkler requirements are determined by a number of different criteria and are dependent on divisions of the building into one or more fire areas. However, in some states, sprinkler requirements may be more restrictive at a local or fire district level. Check with local building and fire jurisdictions to see if local building and/or fire codes have more restrictive requirements, such as for those buildings located in a Wildfire Urban Interface area.

children.body: Fire-resistance-rated protection of risers and laterals of Class II standpipe systems is not required.
A minimum 1-inch (25 mm) hose shall be allowed to be used for hose stations in light-hazard occupancies where investigated and listed for this service and where approved by the fire code official.
Class III standpipe systems shall have hose connections located as required for Class I standpipes in Section 905.4 and shall have Class II hose connections as required in Section 905.5.

diagrams.title: Standpipe System Classes
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Standpipe Systems - There are three classification of standpipes:
  • Class I standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection and are intended for fire department use only.
  • Class II standpipes are equipped with a 1-1/2" hose and connection, and are intended primarily for building occupant use.
  • Class III standpipes are equipped with a 2-1/2" hose connection, reduced down to a 1-1/2" connected hose. These are intended for use by building occupants and fire department personnel.

children.displayTitle: [F]  905.6 Location of Class III Standpipe Hose Connections
children.titleText: Location of Class III Standpipe Hose Connections

children.body: Risers and laterals of Class III standpipe systems shall be protected as required for Class I systems in accordance with Section 905.4.1.
In buildings where more than one Class III standpipe is provided, the standpipes shall be interconnected in accordance with NFPA 14.
Cabinets containing fire-fighting equipment such as standpipes, fire hoses, fire extinguishers or fire department valves shall not be blocked from use or obscured from view.

Cabinets shall be identified in an approved manner by a permanently attached sign with letters not less than 2 inches (51 mm) high in a color that contrasts with the background color, indicating the equipment contained therein.
Exceptions:
  1. Doors not large enough to accommodate a written sign shall be marked with a permanently attached pictogram of the equipment contained therein.
  2. Doors that have either an approved visual identification clear glass panel or a complete glass door panel are not required to be marked.

Cabinets shall be unlocked.
Exceptions:
  1. Visual identification panels of glass or other approved transparent frangible material that is easily broken and allows access.
  2. Approved locking arrangements.
  3. Group I-3 occupancies.

Dry standpipes shall not be installed.
Exception: Where subject to freezing and in accordance with NFPA 14.

Valves controlling water supplies shall be supervised in the open position so that a change in the normal position of the valve will generate a supervisory signal at the supervising station required by Section 903.4. Where a fire alarm system is provided, a signal shall be transmitted to the control unit.
Exceptions:
  1. Valves to underground key or hub valves in roadway boxes do not require supervision.
  2. Valves locked in the normal position and inspected as provided in this code in buildings not equipped with a fire alarm system.
Standpipe systems required during construction and demolition operations shall be provided in accordance with Section 3311.

The fire code official is authorized to require locking caps on the outlets on standpipes where the responding fire department carries key wrenches for the removal that are compatible with locking FDC connection caps.

diagrams.title: Extinguishers: Where Required
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This code section outlines where fire extinguishers are required to be installed. There are exceptions for Groups E, I, R-2, S, and U occupancies. Where fire extinguishers are required the selection, installation, and maintenance of the extinguisher is required to be done in accordance with NFPA 10.

diagrams.title: Example: 1hr Recessed M.E.P. Cabinets
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Items recessed in rated construction must maintain the rating of the wall they are in, and are considered a membrane penetration. This is an example of one method of maintaining protection at items such as panels or fire extinguisher boxes recessed into the wall. Source: OSHPD.CA.GOV. OPD No. FR3.01

diagrams.title: Fire Extinguisher Coverage Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The selection, sizing, and distribution of fire extinguishers is outlined in this section, as referenced in NFPA 10. Selection of an extinguisher is based on the occupancy classification, and size of the area protected.

Example: The space is determined to be a light hazard occupancy (per NFPA 10:5.4.1.1) → the total square footage of the area is 10,000sq.ft. → This space would require a total extinguisher rating of 4-A. However, based on square footage only one extinguisher is required (up to 11,250 sq. ft.). Compliance with this section could be accomplished with one fire extinguisher that has a 4A rating, (2) 2A rated extinguishers or, per note 'c' of Table 906.3(1), (8) 1A rated extinguishers. No matter how the A rating is achieved the extinguisher(s) must be located in such a way so that no person has to travel more than 75' to get to a fire extinguisher.

diagrams.title: Extinguisher Designations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire Extinguisher Designations - All fire extinguishers are tested and rated in accordance with NFPA 10 and UL 711. Extinguishers are rated for the types of fires they will extinguish and for the amount of agent they will expel. The letter designation indicates the type of fire that can be extinguished. Class A - ordinary combustibles; Class B - flammable liquids; Class C- energized electrical equipment; Class D - metal fire; Class K- kitchen fats, oils, and grease. Class A and B extinguishers also have a numerical rating which indicates the amount of agent that is contained within the extinguisher, or the amount of fire that can be extinguished. A 1-A rated extinguisher has an amount of extinguishing agent equivalent to 1.25 gallons of water. A 2-A rated extinguisher has an amount of extinguishing agent equivalent to 2.5 gallons of water. A 1-B rated extinguisher is capable of extinguishing 1 sq.ft. equivalent of a flammable liquid fire.

diagrams.title: Extinguisher Installation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire extinguishers are required to be mounted with the bottom at least 4" above the finished floor. Extinguishers weighing 40lbs or less are to be mounted with the top no higher than 5' AFF. Extinguishers weighing more than 40lbs are to be mounted with the top no higher than 3.5' AFF.

diagrams.title: Domestic Cooking Appliances in Group I-2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group I-2 occupancies the only cooking appliances allowed are ovens, cooktops, ranges, warmers and microwaves. A portable fire extinguisher installed per Section 906 is required to be located within 30' of any cooking appliance. Cooktops and ranges need to be protected in accordance w/ 904.14. A fuel and electric power shut-off accessible only to staff must be provided. A timer(s) shall automatically deactivate all appliances such that each appliance may not operate continuously for more than120 minutes.

children.body:
Portable fire extinguishers shall be installed in all of the following locations:
  1. In Group A, B, E, F, H, I, M, R-1, R-2, R-4 and S occupancies.
    Exceptions:
    1. In Group R-2 occupancies, portable fire extinguishers shall be required only in locations specified in Items 2 through 6 where each dwelling unit is provided with a portable fire extinguisher having a minimum rating of 1-A:10-B:C.
    2. In Group E occupancies. portable fire extinguishers shall be required only in locations specified in Items 2 through 6 where each classroom is provided with a portable fire extinguisher having a minimum rating of 2-A:20-B:C.
    3. In storage areas of Group S Occupancies where forklift, powered industrial truck or powered cart operators are the primary occupants, fixed extinguishers, as specified in NFPA 10, shall not be required where in accordance with all of the following:
      1. Use of vehicle-mounted extinguishers shall be approved by the fire code official.
      2. Each vehicle shall be equipped with a 10-pound, 40A:80B:C extinguisher affixed to the vehicle using a mounting bracket approved by the extinguisher manufacturer or the fire code official for vehicular use.
      3. Not less than two spare extinguishers of equal or greater rating shall be available on site to replace a discharged extinguisher.
      4. Vehicle operators shall be trained in the proper operation, use and inspection of extinguishers.
      5. Inspections of vehicle-mounted extinguishers shall be performed daily.
  2. Within 30 feet (9144 mm) distance of travel from commercial cooking equipment and from domestic cooking equipment in Group I-1; I-2, Condition 1; and R-2 college dormitory occupancies.
  3. In areas where flammable or combustible liquids are stored, used or dispensed.
  4. On each floor of structures under construction, except Group R-3 occupancies, in accordance with Section 3315.1 of the International Fire Code.
  5. Where required by the International Fire Code sections indicated in Table 906.1.
  6. Special-hazard areas, including but not limited to laboratories, computer rooms and generator rooms, where required by the fire code official.
Exception: Portable fire extinguishers are not required at normally unmanned Group U occupancy buildings or structures where a portable fire extinguisher suitable to the hazard of the location is provided on the vehicle of visiting personnel.

diagrams.title: Extinguishers: Where Required
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This code section outlines where fire extinguishers are required to be installed. There are exceptions for Groups E, I, R-2, S, and U occupancies. Where fire extinguishers are required the selection, installation, and maintenance of the extinguisher is required to be done in accordance with NFPA 10.

children.body:
Portable fire extinguishers shall be selected and installed in accordance with this section and NFPA 10.
Exceptions:
  1. The distance of travel to reach an extinguisher shall not apply to the spectator seating portions of Group A-5 occupancies.
  2. In Group I-3, portable fire extinguishers shall be permitted to be located at staff locations.
The size and distribution of portable fire extinguishers shall be in accordance with Sections 906.3.1 through 906.3.4.

diagrams.title: Fire Extinguisher Coverage Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The selection, sizing, and distribution of fire extinguishers is outlined in this section, as referenced in NFPA 10. Selection of an extinguisher is based on the occupancy classification, and size of the area protected.

Example: The space is determined to be a light hazard occupancy (per NFPA 10:5.4.1.1) → the total square footage of the area is 10,000sq.ft. → This space would require a total extinguisher rating of 4-A. However, based on square footage only one extinguisher is required (up to 11,250 sq. ft.). Compliance with this section could be accomplished with one fire extinguisher that has a 4A rating, (2) 2A rated extinguishers or, per note 'c' of Table 906.3(1), (8) 1A rated extinguishers. No matter how the A rating is achieved the extinguisher(s) must be located in such a way so that no person has to travel more than 75' to get to a fire extinguisher.

diagrams.title: Extinguisher Designations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire Extinguisher Designations - All fire extinguishers are tested and rated in accordance with NFPA 10 and UL 711. Extinguishers are rated for the types of fires they will extinguish and for the amount of agent they will expel. The letter designation indicates the type of fire that can be extinguished. Class A - ordinary combustibles; Class B - flammable liquids; Class C- energized electrical equipment; Class D - metal fire; Class K- kitchen fats, oils, and grease. Class A and B extinguishers also have a numerical rating which indicates the amount of agent that is contained within the extinguisher, or the amount of fire that can be extinguished. A 1-A rated extinguisher has an amount of extinguishing agent equivalent to 1.25 gallons of water. A 2-A rated extinguisher has an amount of extinguishing agent equivalent to 2.5 gallons of water. A 1-B rated extinguisher is capable of extinguishing 1 sq.ft. equivalent of a flammable liquid fire.

children.body: The minimum sizes and distribution of portable fire extinguishers for occupancies that involve primarily Class A fire hazards shall comply with Table 906.3(1).

Portable fire extinguishers for occupancies involving flammable or combustible liquids with depths less than or equal to 0.25-inch (6.4 mm) shall be selected and placed in accordance with Table 906.3(2).
Portable fire extinguishers for occupancies involving flammable or combustible liquids with a depth of greater than 0.25-inch (6.4 mm) shall be selected and placed in accordance with NFPA 10.
Portable fire extinguishers for Class C fire hazards shall be selected and placed on the basis of the anticipated Class A or B hazard.
Portable fire extinguishers for occupancies involving combustible metals shall be selected and placed in accordance with NFPA 10.

Fire extinguishers provided for the protection of cooking equipment shall be of an approved type compatible with the automatic fire-extinguishing system agent. Cooking equipment involving solid fuels or vegetable or animal oils and fats shall be protected by a Class K-rated portable extinguisher in accordance with Sections 906.1, Item 2, 906.4.1 and 906.4.2 of the International Fire Code, as applicable.

diagrams.title: Domestic Cooking Appliances in Group I-2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In group I-2 occupancies the only cooking appliances allowed are ovens, cooktops, ranges, warmers and microwaves. A portable fire extinguisher installed per Section 906 is required to be located within 30' of any cooking appliance. Cooktops and ranges need to be protected in accordance w/ 904.14. A fuel and electric power shut-off accessible only to staff must be provided. A timer(s) shall automatically deactivate all appliances such that each appliance may not operate continuously for more than120 minutes.

children.body: Portable fire extinguishers shall be located in conspicuous locations where they will have ready access and be immediately available for use. These locations shall be along normal paths of travel, unless the fire code official determines that the hazard posed indicates the need for placement away from normal paths of travel.

Portable fire extinguishers shall not be obstructed or obscured from view. In rooms or areas in which visual obstruction cannot be completely avoided, means shall be provided to indicate the locations of extinguishers.

Hand-held portable fire extinguishers, not housed in cabinets, shall be installed on the hangers or brackets supplied. Hangers or brackets shall be securely anchored to the mounting surface in accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions.

Cabinets used to house portable fire extinguishers shall not be locked.
Exceptions:
  1. Where portable fire extinguishers subject to malicious use or damage are provided with a means of ready access.
  2. In Group I-3 occupancies and in mental health areas in Group I-2 occupancies, access to portable fire extinguishers shall be permitted to be locked or to be located in staff locations provided that the staff has keys.
The installation of portable fire extinguishers shall be in accordance with Sections 906.9.1 through 906.9.3.

diagrams.title: Extinguishers: Where Required
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This code section outlines where fire extinguishers are required to be installed. There are exceptions for Groups E, I, R-2, S, and U occupancies. Where fire extinguishers are required the selection, installation, and maintenance of the extinguisher is required to be done in accordance with NFPA 10.

diagrams.title: Example: 1hr Recessed M.E.P. Cabinets
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Items recessed in rated construction must maintain the rating of the wall they are in, and are considered a membrane penetration. This is an example of one method of maintaining protection at items such as panels or fire extinguisher boxes recessed into the wall. Source: OSHPD.CA.GOV. OPD No. FR3.01

diagrams.title: Extinguisher Installation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire extinguishers are required to be mounted with the bottom at least 4" above the finished floor. Extinguishers weighing 40lbs or less are to be mounted with the top no higher than 5' AFF. Extinguishers weighing more than 40lbs are to be mounted with the top no higher than 3.5' AFF.

children.body: Portable fire extinguishers having a gross weight not exceeding 40 pounds (18 kg) shall be installed so that their tops are not more than 5 feet (1524 mm) above the floor.
Hand-held portable fire extinguishers having a gross weight exceeding 40 pounds (18 kg) shall be installed so that their tops are not more than 3.5 feet (1067 mm) above the floor.
The clearance between the floor and the bottom of installed hand-held portable fire extinguishers shall be not less than 4 inches (102 mm).
Wheeled fire extinguishers shall be conspicuously located in a designated location.

diagrams.title: Smoke Alarm and Detector - Specific Location Reqs : (1)-(3)
Smoke Alarm and Detector - Specific Location Reqs : (4)-(6)
Smoke Alarm and Detector - Specific Location Reqs (7)-(9)
Smoke Alarm and Detector - Specific Location Reqs (10)-(12)
Recessed Mounting of Detector
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The fundamental smoke detector function depends upon smoke entering the device's sensing chamber. Installing a smoke detector recessed within a ceiling or wall cavity impedes the ability of smoke to enter the sensing chamber. For this reason, 17.5.1 prohibits the practice, unless the device is specifically tested and listed, by a nationally recognized testing agency, for recessed installation.

A common practice for installing smoke detection at the top of an elevator hoistway is to mount it on the inside face of an access panel so it can be serviced without entering the hoistway. Unless the detector is mounted on an extension that locates the entire detector past the vertical plane of the wall (Fig. B) the installation is considered recessed (Fig. A) and must be tested and listed for the purpose.

diagrams.title: Specific Protection Detector Location
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When smoke detection is required to initiate action, such as elevator recall (Section 21.3.5) or protection of fire alarm control equipment (Section 10.4.5), detectors may be located "in close proximity" to the protected equipment. For example, ceilings greater than 15 feet high at elevator lobbies, or above fire alarm control equipment may have detectors installed lower on the wall than specified by 10.4.5 (i.e., within 12" of the ceiling).

It should be noted that if area smoke detection is otherwise required, the detectors should be installed at the ceiling and serve to meet both the area detection and equipment protection objectives.

Smoke detectors installed within 60" of the equipment or hazard being protected are considered to be "in close proximity". Such detectors are more accessible for inspection, testing and maintenance, while ensuring detection occurs before the equipment/hazard is compromised by smoke. Since elevator lobby detectors are not installed on the ceiling, the 60" criteria should be applied individually to each elevator opening. It is not appropriate to use the 21 foot radius permitted by 21.3.5.1 for wall mounted detectors.

diagrams.title: Smoke Stratification Effects
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The design and spacing of smoke detection must account for the potential of smoke stratification. Smoke stratification occurs when the ambient temperature matches that of the fire plume, such that the the smoke loses buoyancy and ceases to rise. The primary factors contributing to smoke stratification include:
  • Ceiling height above fire (H).
  • Change in ambient temperature between the lower and upper compartment (▲T).
  • Heat release rate (HRR) of probable fire scenario.
Smoke stratification is of increasing concern when ceiling elevations exceed 30 feet above the design fire, when high temperature gradients are expected between the floor and ceiling, where skylights add solar gain to the upper compartment elevation, and when low heat release, smoldering fires are likely. Annex B of the standard provides additional guidance to evaluate stratification potential.

When the potential exists for smoke stratification, ceiling mounted detectors may be ineffective and other means of detection should be considered, including, but not limited to beam detection, air sampling, multi-level detectors, or video smoke detection.

diagrams.title: Partition Impact on Detector Spacing
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Key to activation of a smoke or heat detector is the ceiling jet velocity created by the fire plume, which is generally accepted to be 10% of the ceiling height. Partial height partitions in a space with complete smoke or heat detection have the potential impede the ceiling jet, thus delaying smoke or heat from reaching the nearest detector. The standard conservatively prescribes that partitions whose height extend to within 15% of the ceiling height be treated as full height partitions. The spaces on either side are then considered separate rooms for detector spacing purposes.

The diagram shows a partial height partition that does not extend across the entire space. Since the partition extends to within 15% of the ceiling height, the spaces with partition separation are treated as unique rooms, for detector spacing, while the portion without is not. The designer might elect to maximize detector spacing per 17.6.3.1.1(2), thus minimizing the number of detectors required for compliance.

diagrams.title: Detectors at Loading Docks
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In buildings otherwise required to have total (complete) detection, spaces under open loading docks/platforms and accessible underfloor spaces may omit detection if all conditions 1-6 are satisfied. Although the standard treats them as four conditions, the first contains three criteria that are broken out separately below.
Allowable heat/smoke detector omissions:
  1. Space is not accessible for storage.
  2. The space is not accessible by unauthorized persons.
  3. Space is protected against accumulation of windborne debris.
  4. The space contains no equipment that could potentially serve as an ignition source or path for fire extension from other areas.
  5. The the dock, platform or floor surface above the space is sufficiently tight to prevent passage of any combustible material to the space below.
  6. The dock, platform or floor above the space may not be used for processing, storage or handling of flammable liquids.
  7. Despite condition 4 of a "tight" floor, spilled flammable liquids could still reach the concealed area.

diagrams.title: Detector Coverage - Return-air Plenums
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When total smoke/heat detector coverage is required by other governing laws, codes or standards, air plenum space must also include smoke detection. There are two options to provide compliant detection in return air plenums. The plenum must meet all applicable provisions of NFPA 90A.

Allowable plenum space detection options:
  1. Install compliant area detection using detectors listed suitable for the environment, including air velocity, ,temperature, and humidity anticipated within the plenum. Access must also be provided to the plenum to service, inspect and test the detectors.
  2. Where connections from the plenum that return air to the air-handling system are clearly defined, it may be more efficient to provide detection at such connections.
Regardless of the selected option, complete detection is required for the room below the plenum. Detection in the return air system does not meet the detection requirement for the room below.

diagrams.title: Smoke Detector Location: Ceiling or Wall Mounted
Smoke Detector Spacing - Smooth Ceiling
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In the absence of specific performance-based design criteria or conflicting manufacturer's instructions, spot-type smoke detectors are to be located using one of the two methods in this section. The first method requires a maximum of 30 feet between detectors and a maximum of 15 feet from walls, measured perpendicular to the wall. Walls extending to within 15 percent of the ceiling height must be treated as full height walls (see 17.5.2). Although this method may work well for rectangular spaces (particularly if dimensions are multiples of 30 ft.), it is less efficient for long, narrow spaces (e.g. corridors) or non-rectangular spaces.

The nominal 30 foot (S) and 15 foot (/S) spacing criteria may be exceeded, so long as a detector is located within 21 feet (0.7S) of all points on the ceiling. This provision recognizes that smoke migrates radially from a fire and that corners of a 30'x30' square are just over 21 feet from its center, as shown in Figure 1. Figure 2 shows detector spacing strictly adhering to 30'x30' spacing per 17.7.4.2.3.1(1), which results in a design with 30 smoke detectors. Figure 3 shows detector coverage within 21 feet (0.7 x 30) of all points on the ceiling, such that only 25 detectors provide compliant spacing. Minor adjustments from Figure 1, to meet 0.7S in the main hall and perimeter corridor, provide more efficient detector coverage. Maximum efficiency is met using 30'x30' spacing in the balance of the building due to space dimensions that are multiples of 30'.

diagrams.title: Duct Smoke Detector Location - Installation Methods
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
This section recognizes four methods of detecting smoke within air duct systems. Regardless of the selected method, the smoke detector must be listed for the application, installed in accordance with the manufacturer's installation requirements, and accessible for inspection and cleaning. The detector must specifically be listed for the anticipated air velocity, temperature, and humidity ranges expected within the duct.

Method 1: Rigid mounting within the duct uses a spot-type smoke detector. Vibration induced by continuous air-flow can loosen the installation over time, so rigidity is essential for detector mounting.

Method 2: Rigid mounting to the wall of the duct with the sensing element protruding into the duct is more appropriate for duct sections less than about 18 inches where the detector is more likely exposed to a representative sample air-flow. As with method 1, rigid installation is important to minimize the effects of vibration over time.

Method 3: Installation outside the duct with rigidly mounted sampling tubes protruding into the duct refers to detector in a housing, purpose manufactured to detect smoke within the duct, with the detector entirely outside of the duct. The sampling tubes cause air to flow through the sampling tube, across the detector (within enclosed housing), and return to the duct. Rigid mounting of the sampling tube generally requires penetration of the opposite side of the duct when the duct exceeds 36 inches in width. Very wide ducts may require internal support for the sampling tube to ensure rigidity.

Method 4: Installation through the duct with projected light beam is a less common application. A beam-type detector is installed on the duct exterior with a hole through which the beam will project on to a receiver on the opposite side. This method is less subject to damage by vibration or reduced effectiveness from dust accumulation due to limited equipment inside the duct.

diagrams.title: Smoke Detector Spacing - Solid Joist/Beam Const., Item 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Solid beams and joists equally impede smoke flow to the nearest detector, so they are treated the same with respect to smoke detector spacing. When beams or joists are present on level ceilings, detector spacing and location depends on one or more of three dimensions:
  1. Depth of solid beam/joist.
  2. Height of compartment from finish floor to ceiling.
  3. Distance between beams/joists.

diagrams.title: Smoke Detector Spacing - Solid Joist/Beam Const., Item 3a
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Solid beams and joists equally impede smoke flow to the nearest detector, so they are treated the same with respect to smoke detector spacing. When beams or joists are present on level ceilings, detector spacing and location depends on one or more of three dimensions:
  1. Depth of solid beam/joist.
  2. Height of compartment from finish floor to ceiling.
  3. Distance between beams/joists.

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Solid beams and joists equally impede smoke flow to the nearest detector, so they are treated the same with respect to smoke detector spacing. When beams or joists are present on level ceilings, detector spacing and location depends on one or more of three dimensions:
  1. Depth of solid beam/joist.
  2. Height of compartment from finish floor to ceiling.
  3. Distance between beams/joists.

diagrams.title: Smoke Detector Spacing - Solid Joist/Beam Const., Item 3b
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Solid beams and joists equally impede smoke flow to the nearest detector, so they are treated the same with respect to smoke detector spacing. When beams or joists are present on level ceilings, detector spacing and location depends on one or more of three dimensions:
  1. Depth of solid beam/joist.
  2. Height of compartment from finish floor to ceiling.
  3. Distance between beams/joists.

diagrams.title: Smoke Detector Spacing - Solid Joist/Beam Const., Item 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Solid beams and joists equally impede smoke flow to the nearest detector, so they are treated the same with respect to smoke detector spacing. When beams or joists are present on level ceilings, detector spacing and location depends on one or more of three dimensions:
  1. Depth of solid beam/joist.
  2. Height of compartment from finish floor to ceiling.
  3. Distance between beams/joists.

Corridors equal or less than 15 feet wide and rooms equal or less than 900 square feet have no unique spacing criteria, regardless of presence or depth of beams or joists. Beams or joists in such spaces have been shown to have little impact to detector activation, when the basic detector spacing criteria of 17.7.4.2.3.1 are satisfied. However, extreme beam depths in such spaces should be scrutinized from a performance perspective.

diagrams.title: Smoke Detector Spacing - Solid Joist/Beam Const., Item 5
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Solid beams and joists equally impede smoke flow to the nearest detector, so they are treated the same with respect to smoke detector spacing. When beams or joists are present on level ceilings, detector spacing and location depends on one or more of three dimensions:
  1. Depth of solid beam/joist.
  2. Height of compartment from finish floor to ceiling.
  3. Distance between beams/joists.

diagrams.title: Complete Coverage - Detector Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Buildings (or portions thereof) requiring total/complete automatic smoke/heat detection must have detectors installed in all rooms, halls, storage areas, basements, attics, lofts, spaces above suspended ceilings, and other subdivisions and accessible spaces.

It is important to note that NFPA 72 does not specify when detection is required, but rather how and were to install it when required by other governing laws, codes, or standards (e.g., fire code, building code, state law, local ordinance, etc.).

Despite the general 17.5.3.1 requirement for "complete detection", the standard recognizes that some building areas are not suitable for detection, due to environmental conditions, limited access or lack of fire potential. Subsections 17.5.3.1.1 through 17.5.3.1.5 clarify conditions that must be met to omit detection in such spaces.

This diagram visually represents a building that satisfies the standard for total (complete) detection coverage. See noted sub-section diagrams for clarity on permissible detector omissions.

diagrams.title: Nursing Home Areas Open to Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2, Condition 1 nursing home areas, shared living, meeting, or therapeutic spaces may open directly to corridors if specific safety requirements are met. These include constructing walls and ceilings to corridor standards, ensuring the spaces are not used for sleeping, treatment, hazardous, or incidental uses, and providing automatic fire detection systems. Additionally, corridors in the same smoke compartment must have fire detection or the compartment must have quick response sprinklers, and the layout must maintain clear access to required exits.

diagrams.title: Smoke Activated Door Closers and Hold-Opens
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire doors that are required to close automatically may be held open by a hold-open device. The hold-open device is required to released the door when any of the following conditions occur:
  1. Smoke detectors are activated
  2. Loss of power to the smoke detector occurs
  3. Loss of power to the hold-open device occurs

children.displayTitle: Section 907 Fire Alarm and Detection Systems

children.body: This section covers the application, installation, performance and maintenance of fire alarm systems and their components.

Construction documents for fire alarm systems shall be of sufficient clarity to indicate the location, nature and extent of the work proposed and show in detail that it will conform to the provisions of this code, the International Fire Code; and relevant laws, ordinances, rules and regulations, as determined by the fire code official.
Shop drawings for fire alarm systems shall be prepared in accordance with NFPA 72 and submitted for review and approval prior to system installation.
Systems and components shall be listed and approved for the purpose for which they are installed.

An approved fire alarm system installed in accordance with the provisions of this code and NFPA 72 shall be provided in new buildings and structures in accordance with Sections 907.2.1 through 907.2.23 and provide occupant notification in accordance with Section 907.5, unless other requirements are provided by another section of this code.
Not fewer than one manual fire alarm box shall be provided in an approved location to initiate a fire alarm signal for fire alarm systems employing automatic fire detectors or waterflow detection devices. Where other sections of this code allow elimination of fire alarm boxes due to sprinklers, a single fire alarm box shall be installed.
Exceptions:
  1. The manual fire alarm box is not required for fire alarm systems dedicated to elevator recall control and supervisory service.
  2. The manual fire alarm box is not required for Group R-2 occupancies unless required by the fire code official to provide a means for fire watch personnel to initiate an alarm during a sprinkler system impairment event. Where provided, the manual fire alarm box shall not be located in an area that is open to the public.

diagrams.title: Fire Alarm Notification Zones
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Zones, Notification - Fire alarm system components are separated into zones, areas that activate simultaneously. Per NFPA 72, these areas, zones, are within the natural boundaries of the building, enclosed by fire or smoke barriers, or designated by separate floors.

diagrams.title: Fire Alarm: Group B Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A fire alarm system, installed in accordance with NFPA 72, is required throughout all business occupancies that have a total occupant load of 500 or more, or an occupant load of more than 100 above and/or below the level of exit discharge. Pull stations or, manual fire alarm boxes, are not required when the building has an automatic fire sprinkler system in place. However, at least one manual pull station is required as stated in WFC 907.2, "Where other sections of this code allow elimination of fire alarm boxes due to sprinklers, a single fire alarm box shall be installed." This alarm pull station is most often installed near the fire alarm control panel. Additionally, when a business occupancy contains an ambulatory care facility, the facility must have automatic smoke detection installed throughout, including into public corridors and elevator lobbies. These may be omitted if the building is fully sprinklered.

diagrams.title: Fire Alarm: Group A Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A fire alarm system, installed in accordance with NFPA 72, is required throughout all assembly occupancies that have an occupant load of 300 or more, or an occupant load of more than 100 above and/or below the level of exit discharge. Pull stations or, manual fire alarm boxes, are not required when the building has an automatic fire sprinkler system in place. However, at least one manual pull station is required as stated in FC section 907.2, "Where other sections of this code allow elimination of fire alarm boxes due to sprinklers, a single fire alarm box shall be installed." This alarm pull station is most often installed near the fire alarm control panel.

children.body:
A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5 shall be installed in Group A occupancies where the occupant load due to the assembly occupancy is 300 or more, or where the Group A occupant load is more than 100 persons above or below the lowest level of exit discharge. Group A occupancies not separated from one another in accordance with Section 707.3.10 shall be considered as a single occupancy for the purposes of applying this section. Portions of Group E occupancies occupied for assembly purposes shall be provided with a fire alarm system as required for the Group E occupancy.
Exception: Manual fire alarm boxes are not required where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 and the occupant notification appliances will activate throughout the notification zones upon sprinkler water flow.

diagrams.title: Fire Alarm: Group A Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A fire alarm system, installed in accordance with NFPA 72, is required throughout all assembly occupancies that have an occupant load of 300 or more, or an occupant load of more than 100 above and/or below the level of exit discharge. Pull stations or, manual fire alarm boxes, are not required when the building has an automatic fire sprinkler system in place. However, at least one manual pull station is required as stated in FC section 907.2, "Where other sections of this code allow elimination of fire alarm boxes due to sprinklers, a single fire alarm box shall be installed." This alarm pull station is most often installed near the fire alarm control panel.

children.body:
Activation of the fire alarm in Group A occupancies with an occupant load of 1,000 or more shall initiate a signal using an emergency voice/alarm communications system in accordance with Section 907.5.2.2.
Exception: Where approved, the prerecorded announcement is allowed to be manually deactivated for a period of time, not to exceed 3 minutes, for the sole purpose of allowing a live voice announcement from an approved, constantly attended location.

diagrams.title: Fire Alarm: Group A Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A fire alarm system, installed in accordance with NFPA 72, is required throughout all assembly occupancies that have an occupant load of 300 or more, or an occupant load of more than 100 above and/or below the level of exit discharge. Pull stations or, manual fire alarm boxes, are not required when the building has an automatic fire sprinkler system in place. However, at least one manual pull station is required as stated in FC section 907.2, "Where other sections of this code allow elimination of fire alarm boxes due to sprinklers, a single fire alarm box shall be installed." This alarm pull station is most often installed near the fire alarm control panel.

children.displayTitle: [F]  907.2.1.1 System Initiation in Group A Occupancies With an Occupant Load of 1,000 or More
children.titleText: System Initiation in Group A Occupancies With an Occupant Load of 1,000 or More

children.body: Stadiums, arenas and grandstands required to caption audible public announcements shall be in accordance with Section 907.5.2.2.4.

A manual fire alarm system, which activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5, shall be installed in Group B occupancies where one of the following conditions exists:
  1. The combined Group B occupant load of all floors is 500 or more.
  2. The Group B occupant load is more than 100 persons above or below the lowest level of exit discharge.
  3. The fire area contains an ambulatory care facility.
Exception: Manual fire alarm boxes are not required where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 and the occupant notification appliances will activate throughout the notification zones upon sprinkler water flow.

diagrams.title: Fire Alarm: Group B Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A fire alarm system, installed in accordance with NFPA 72, is required throughout all business occupancies that have a total occupant load of 500 or more, or an occupant load of more than 100 above and/or below the level of exit discharge. Pull stations or, manual fire alarm boxes, are not required when the building has an automatic fire sprinkler system in place. However, at least one manual pull station is required as stated in WFC 907.2, "Where other sections of this code allow elimination of fire alarm boxes due to sprinklers, a single fire alarm box shall be installed." This alarm pull station is most often installed near the fire alarm control panel. Additionally, when a business occupancy contains an ambulatory care facility, the facility must have automatic smoke detection installed throughout, including into public corridors and elevator lobbies. These may be omitted if the building is fully sprinklered.

children.body:
Fire areas containing ambulatory care facilities shall be provided with an electronically supervised automatic smoke detection system installed within the ambulatory care facility and in public use areas outside of tenant spaces, including public corridors and elevator lobbies.
Exception: Buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, provided that the occupant notification appliances will activate throughout the notification zones upon sprinkler waterflow.

diagrams.title: Fire Alarm: Group B Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A fire alarm system, installed in accordance with NFPA 72, is required throughout all business occupancies that have a total occupant load of 500 or more, or an occupant load of more than 100 above and/or below the level of exit discharge. Pull stations or, manual fire alarm boxes, are not required when the building has an automatic fire sprinkler system in place. However, at least one manual pull station is required as stated in WFC 907.2, "Where other sections of this code allow elimination of fire alarm boxes due to sprinklers, a single fire alarm box shall be installed." This alarm pull station is most often installed near the fire alarm control panel. Additionally, when a business occupancy contains an ambulatory care facility, the facility must have automatic smoke detection installed throughout, including into public corridors and elevator lobbies. These may be omitted if the building is fully sprinklered.

diagrams.title: Smoke Detector Spacing - Smooth Ceiling
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In the absence of specific performance-based design criteria or conflicting manufacturer's instructions, spot-type smoke detectors are to be located using one of the two methods in this section. The first method requires a maximum of 30 feet between detectors and a maximum of 15 feet from walls, measured perpendicular to the wall. Walls extending to within 15 percent of the ceiling height must be treated as full height walls (see 17.5.2). Although this method may work well for rectangular spaces (particularly if dimensions are multiples of 30 ft.), it is less efficient for long, narrow spaces (e.g. corridors) or non-rectangular spaces.

The nominal 30 foot (S) and 15 foot (/S) spacing criteria may be exceeded, so long as a detector is located within 21 feet (0.7S) of all points on the ceiling. This provision recognizes that smoke migrates radially from a fire and that corners of a 30'x30' square are just over 21 feet from its center, as shown in Figure 1. Figure 2 shows detector spacing strictly adhering to 30'x30' spacing per 17.7.4.2.3.1(1), which results in a design with 30 smoke detectors. Figure 3 shows detector coverage within 21 feet (0.7 x 30) of all points on the ceiling, such that only 25 detectors provide compliant spacing. Minor adjustments from Figure 1, to meet 0.7S in the main hall and perimeter corridor, provide more efficient detector coverage. Maximum efficiency is met using 30'x30' spacing in the balance of the building due to space dimensions that are multiples of 30'.

children.body:
Group E occupancies shall be provided with a manual fire alarm system that initiates the occupant notification signal utilizing one of the following:
  1. An emergency voice/alarm communication system meeting the requirements of Section 907.5.2.2 and installed in accordance with Section 907.6; or
  2. A system developed as part of a safe school plan adopted in accordance with RCW 28A.320.125 or developed as part of an emergency response system consistent with the provisions of RCW 28A.320.126. The system must achieve all of the following performance standards:
    1. The ability to broadcast voice messages or customized announcements;
    2. Includes a feature for multiple sounds, including sounds to initiate a lock down;
    3. The ability to deliver messages to the interior of a building, areas outside of a building as designated pursuant to the safe school plan, and to personnel;
    4. The ability for two-way communications;
    5. The ability for individual room calling;
    6. The ability for a manual override;
    7. Installation in accordance with NFPA 72;
    8. Provide 15 minutes of battery backup for alarm and 24 hours of battery backup for standby; and
    9. Includes a program for annual inspection and maintenance in accordance with NFPA 72.
EXCEPTIONS:
  1. A manual fire alarm system shall not be required in Group E occupancies with an occupant load of 50 or less.
  2. Emergency voice/alarm communication systems meeting the requirements of Section 907.5.2.2 and installed in accordance with Section 907.6 shall not be required in Group E occupancies with occupant loads of 100 or less, such as individual portable school classroom buildings; provided that activation of the manual fire alarm system initiates an approved occupant notification signal in accordance with Section 907.5.
  3. Where an existing approved alarm system is in place, an emergency voice/alarm system is not required in any portion of an existing Group E building undergoing any one of the following repairs, alteration or addition:
    1. Alteration or repair to an existing building including, without limitation, alterations to rooms and systems, and/or corridor configurations, not exceeding 35 percent of the fire area of the building (or the fire area undergoing the alteration or repair if the building is comprised of two or more fire areas); or
    2. An addition to an existing building, not exceeding 35 percent of the fire area of the building (or the fire area to which the addition is made if the building is comprised of two or more fire areas).
  4. Manual fire alarm boxes shall not be required in Group E occupancies where all of the following apply:
    1. Interior corridors are protected by smoke detectors.
    2. Auditoriums, cafeterias, gymnasiums and similar areas are protected by heat detectors or other approved detection devices.
    3. Shops and laboratories involving dust or vapors are protected by heat detectors or other approved detection devices.
    4. Manual activation is provided from a normally occupied location.
  5. Manual fire alarm boxes shall not be required in Group E occupancies where all of the following apply:

    1. The building is equipped throughout with an approved automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.
    2. The emergency voice/alarm communication system will activate on sprinkler waterflow.
    3. Manual activation is provided from a normally occupied location.

diagrams.title: Child Care as Group E
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Day cares are typically classified as Group I-4 occupancies. However, they may be classified as a Group E when the building serves a total occupant load of 6-100 persons, under the age of 2-1/2 years, and each room has an exit directly to the outside at the level of exit discharge.

children.body: When automatic sprinkler systems or smoke detectors are installed, such systems or detectors shall be connected to the building fire alarm system.

A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5 shall be installed in Group F occupancies where both of the following conditions exist:
  1. The Group F occupancy is two or more stories in height.
  2. The Group F occupancy has a combined occupant load of 500 or more above or below the lowest level of exit discharge.
Exception: Manual fire alarm boxes are not required where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 and the occupant notification appliances will activate throughout the notification zones upon sprinkler water flow.

A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5 shall be installed in Group H-5 occupancies and in occupancies used for the manufacture of organic coatings. An automatic smoke detection system shall be installed for highly toxic gases, organic peroxides and oxidizers in accordance with Chapters 60, 62 and 63, respectively, of the International Fire Code.

children.body:
A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5 shall be installed in Group I occupancies. An automatic smoke detection system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5 shall be provided in accordance with Sections 907.2.6.1, 907.2.6.2 and 907.2.6.3.3.
Exceptions:
  1. Manual fire alarm boxes in sleeping units of Group I-1 and I-2 occupancies shall not be required at exits if located at all care providers' control stations or other constantly attended staff locations, provided that such manual fire alarm boxes are visible and provided with ready access, and the distances of travel required in Section 907.4.2.1 are not exceeded.
  2. Occupant notification systems are not required to be activated where private mode signaling installed in accordance with NFPA 72 is approved by the fire code official and staff evacuation responsibilities are included in the fire safety and evacuation plan required by Section 404 of the International Fire Code.

children.body:
In Group I-1 occupancies, an automatic smoke detection system shall be installed in corridors, waiting areas open to corridors and habitable spaces other than sleeping units and kitchens. The system shall be activated in accordance with Section 907.5.
Exceptions:
  1. For Group I-1, Condition 1 occupancies, smoke detection in habitable spaces is not required where the facility is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.
  2. Smoke detection is not required for exterior balconies.

children.body: Single- and multiple-station smoke alarms shall be installed in accordance with Section 907.2.11.

An automatic smoke detection system shall be installed in corridors in Group I-2, Condition 1 facilities and spaces permitted to be open to the corridors by Section 407.2. The system shall be activated in accordance with Section 907.4. Group I-2, Condition 2 occupancies shall be equipped with an automatic smoke detection system as required in Section 407.
Exceptions:
  1. Corridor smoke detection is not required in smoke compartments that contain sleeping units where such units are provided with smoke detectors that comply with UL 268. Such detectors shall provide a visual display on the corridor side of each sleeping unit and shall provide an audible and visual alarm at the care providers' station attending each unit.
  2. Corridor smoke detection is not required in smoke compartments that contain sleeping units where sleeping unit doors are equipped with automatic door-closing devices with integral smoke detectors on the unit sides installed in accordance with their listing, provided that the integral detectors perform the required alerting function.

children.body: Group I-3 occupancies shall be equipped with a manual fire alarm system and automatic smoke detection system installed for alerting staff.

children.body: Actuation of an automatic fire-extinguishing system, automatic sprinkler system, a manual fire alarm box or a fire detector shall initiate an approved fire alarm signal that automatically notifies staff.

Manual fire alarm boxes are not required to be located in accordance with Section 907.4.2 where the fire alarm boxes are provided at staff-attended locations having direct supervision over areas where manual fire alarm boxes have been omitted.

Manual fire alarm boxes are allowed to be locked in areas occupied by detainees, provided that staff members are present within the subject area and have keys readily available to operate the manual fire alarm boxes.
children.displayTitle: [F]  907.2.6.3.2.1 Manual Fire Alarm Boxes in Detainee Areas
children.titleText: Manual Fire Alarm Boxes in Detainee Areas

children.body:
An automatic smoke detection system shall be installed throughout resident housing areas, including sleeping units and contiguous day rooms, group activity spaces and other common spaces normally open to residents.
Exceptions:
  1. Other approved smoke detection arrangements providing equivalent protection, including, but not limited to, placing detectors in exhaust ducts from cells or behind protective guards listed for the purpose, are allowed where necessary to prevent damage or tampering.
  2. Sleeping units in Use Conditions 2 and 3 as described in Section 308.
  3. Smoke detectors are not required in sleeping units with four or fewer occupants in smoke compartments that are equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.

diagrams.title: Smoke Detector Spacing - Smooth Ceiling
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In the absence of specific performance-based design criteria or conflicting manufacturer's instructions, spot-type smoke detectors are to be located using one of the two methods in this section. The first method requires a maximum of 30 feet between detectors and a maximum of 15 feet from walls, measured perpendicular to the wall. Walls extending to within 15 percent of the ceiling height must be treated as full height walls (see 17.5.2).
